name: Good Film
reviewBody:
Sherlock Holmes and the Secret Weapon (1943) 

*** (out of 4) 

Second in Universal's series has Holmes (Basil Rathbone) and Watson (Nigel Bruce) trying to protect a scientist who has created bomb sight, which needs to stay away from German hands. Not only must Holmes have to keep an eye out for the Nazis but the biggest problem might be the trader Professor Moriarty (Lionel Atwill). This is a pretty thrilling adventure for the series and manages to have a great ending, which has some nice tension as Holmes is slowly having the blood drained from his body while the police and Watson try to find his location. Once again the screenplay, dealing with the German's wanting to find a scientist, isn't very original but it's fun enough to keep the film moving well for its short running time. Rathbone once again turns in a very strong performance as Holmes and his charm and wit are on full display and mixes well with Bruce's sometimes dimwitted Dr. Watson. A great bonus is having someone like Atwill playing the bad guy. Both Atwill and Rathbone don't miss a step in their banter towards one another, which they did greatly four years earlier in Son of Frankenstein. Roy William Neill was a very underrated director and he does a fine job here at keeping the film moving at a very fast pace and he nicely adds up the tension towards the end.
